idioms.sense: what a person actually does means more than what they say they will do

idioms.text: be on speaking terms (with somebody) | be speaking (to somebody)
idioms.sense: to be willing to be polite or friendly towards somebody, especially after an argument
examples: She's not been on speaking terms with her uncle for years.
Are they speaking to each other again yet?
We are still on speaking terms after the argument.
Ed and Dave aren't speaking at the moment.

idioms.sense: it is not necessary to give any further explanation about something because the information that is available already proves that it is true

idioms.text: generally, broadly, roughly, relatively, etc. speaking
idioms.sense: used to show that what you are saying is true in a general, etc. way
examples: Generally speaking, the more you pay, the more you get.
There are, broadly speaking, two ways of doing this.
Personally speaking, I've always preferred Italian food.
Women generally earn less than men.
Generally speaking, jobs traditionally done by women are paid at a lower rate than those traditionally done by men.
In general/By and large, women do not earn as much as men.
Certain jobs, like nursing and cleaning, are still mainly carried out by women.
Senior management posts are predominantly held by men.
Most senior management posts tend to be held by men.
Women are, for the most part, still paid less than men.
Economic and social factors are, to a large extent, responsible for women being concentrated in low-paid jobs.

idioms.sense: if you think about it in a particular way; true in some but not all ways
examples: All these points of view are related, in a manner of speaking.

idioms.sense: such a small amount that it is not worth mentioning
examples: They've got no friends to speak of.
She's saved a little money but nothing to speak of.

idioms.sense: used to emphasize that you are expressing something in an unusual or humorous way
examples: They were all very similar. All cut from the same cloth, so to speak.

idioms.sense: to be so easy to see and understand that you do not need to say anything else about it/them
examples: Her success speaks for itself.
Recent events speak for themselves.

idioms.sense: to express what you think or want yourself, rather than somebody else doing it for you
examples: I'm quite capable of speaking for myself, thank you!

idioms.sense: used to tell somebody that a general statement they have just made is not true of you
examples: ‘We didn't play very well.’ ‘Speak for yourself!’ (= I think that I played well.)

idioms.sense: to say or think bad things about somebody
examples: Don't speak ill of the dead.

idioms.sense: used to say that you are the type of person mentioned and are expressing your opinion from that point of view
examples: Speaking as a parent, I'm very concerned about standards in education.

idioms.sense: to say exactly what you think, in a very direct way
examples: She’s never hesitated about speaking her mind.
Everyone should have the right to speak their mind.

idioms.sense: people say speak/talk of the devil when somebody they have been talking about appears unexpectedly
examples: Well, speak of the devil—here's Alice now!

idioms.sense: to say something when you should not, for example because it is not the right time or you are not the right person to say it
to say something that you should not because it is the wrong situation or because it offends somebody
to be able to communicate easily with another person because you share similar opinions and experience
to tell you a lot about something/somebody, without the need for words
examples: His achievement speaks volumes for his determination.
What you wear speaks volumes about you.

idioms.sense: to say good or bad things about somebody
examples: She never speaks ill of anyone.

idioms.sense: if you are using words or rules in their exact or correct sense
examples: Strictly speaking, the book is not a novel, but a short story.
Using the word in that context is not, strictly speaking, correct.
